text: CS 100 Computer Science Orientation. Introduction to Computer Science as a field and career for incoming first year and external transfer students in
external transfer students in the computer science majors. Overview of the field and specific examples of problem areas and methods of solution.
and methods of solution. Restrictions: Restricted to First Time Freshman students. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 101 Intro Computing: Engrg & Sci. Fundamental principles, concepts, and methods of computing, with emphasis on applications in the physical
applications in the physical sciences and engineering. Basic problem solving and programming techniques; fundamental algorithms and data structures;
and data structures; use of computers in solving engineering and scientific problems. Intended for engineering and science majors. Restrictions:
science majors. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..

of computer system components: hardware, systems and applications software, and networks. Widely used application packages such as spreadsheets and
such as spreadsheets and databases. Concepts and practice of programming for the solution of simple problems in different application areas. Intended
application areas. Intended for non-science and non-engineering majors. Prerequisites: MATH 112. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad -
Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..

property, freedom of information, and privacy. Credit is not given for both CS 210 and either CS 211 or ECE 316. Prerequisites: CS 225. Restrictions:
CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to O/C Engineering City Scholars students. Restricted to Undergrad -

CS 211 Ethical and Professional Conduct. Navigating the complex ethical and professional landscape of the computing professional: privacy,
professional: privacy, intellectual property, cybersecurity, and freedom of speech. Hands-on exercises, assignments, and discussions in which
and discussions in which students analyze current events from perspectives in both philosophical and professional ethics. Writing professionally and
Writing professionally and technically in several writing assignments requiring peer review, workshops, and multiple rounds of editing and revising.
of editing and revising. Credit is not given for both CS 211 and CS 210 or ECE 316. Prerequisites: CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad -

CS 222 Software Design Lab. Design and implementation of novel software solutions. Problem identification and definition; idea generation and
idea generation and evaluation; and software implementation, testing, and deployment. Emphasizes software development best practices—including
best practices—including framework selection, code review, documentation, appropriate library usage, project management, continuous integration and
continuous integration and testing, and teamwork. Prerequisites: CS 128; credit or concurrent registration in CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to
Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to O/C Engineering City Scholars students. Restricted to Undergrad -
Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to CS and blended CS majors students..
CS 225 Data Structures. Data abstractions: elementary data structures (lists, stacks, queues, and trees) and their implementation using an
their implementation using an object-oriented programming language. Solutions to a variety of computational problems such as search on graphs and
such as search on graphs and trees. Elementary analysis of algorithms. Credit is not given toward graduation for: CS 277 if credit for CS 225 has
277 if credit for CS 225 has been earned. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to James Scholars Program students.

CS 233 Computer Architecture. Fundamentals of computer architecture: digital logic design, working up from the logic gate level to understand the
gate level to understand the function of a simple computer; machine-level programming to understand implementation of high-level languages;
of high-level languages; performance models of modern computer architectures to enable performance optimization of software; hardware primitives for
hardware primitives for parallelism and security. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to CS and blended CS majors
to CS and blended CS majors students. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to CS and

text: learning in the context of solving data-centric problems. A broad coverage of fundamental models is presented, including linear models, unsupervised

text: linear models, unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and deep learning. A significant emphasis is placed on the application of the models in

text: CS 340 Introduction to Computer Systems. Basics of computer systems. Number representations, assembly/machine language, abstract models of processors
abstract models of processors (fetch/execute, memory hierarchy), processes/process control, simple memory management, file I/O and directories,
file I/O and directories, network programming, usage of cloud services. Credit is not given for both CS 340 and CS 240. Prerequisites: CS 128 and CS
Prerequisites: CS 128 and CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 341 System Programming. Basics of system programming, including POSIX processes, process control, inter-process communication, synchronization,
synchronization, signals, simple memory management, file I/O and directories, shell programming, socket network programming, RPC programming in
RPC programming in distributed systems, basic security mechanisms, and standard tools for systems programming such as debugging tools. Credit is not
tools. Credit is not given for both CS 341 and either CS 241 or ECE 391. Prerequisites: CS 225 and CS 233. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad -
Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to O/C Engineering City Scholars students..
CS 357 Numerical Methods I. Fundamentals of numerical methods for students in science and engineering; floating-point computation, systems of linear
systems of linear equations, approximation of functions and integrals, the single nonlinear equation, and the numerical solution of ordinary
solution of ordinary differential equations; various applications in science and engineering; programming exercises and use of high quality
and use of high quality mathematical library routines. Same as MATH 357. Credit is not given towards graduation for CS 357 if credit for CS 450 has
357 if credit for CS 450 has been earned. (Counts for advanced hours in LAS). Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to
Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 361 Probability & Statistics for Computer Science. Introduction to probability theory and statistics with applications to computer science. Topics
to computer science. Topics include: visualizing datasets, summarizing data, basic descriptive statistics, conditional probability, independence,
probability, independence, Bayes theorem, random variables, joint and conditional distributions, expectation, variance and covariance, central limit
and covariance, central limit theorem. Markov inequality, Chebyshev inequality, law of large numbers, Markov chains, simulation, the PageRank
simulation, the PageRank algorithm, populations and sampling, sample mean, standard error, maximum likelihood estimation, Bayes estimation,
estimation, Bayes estimation, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, linear regression, principal component analysis, classification, and decision
classification, and decision trees. Same as STAT 361. Credit is not given for both CS 361 and ECE 313. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad -
Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 374 Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation. Analysis of algorithms, major paradigms of algorithm design including recursive algorithms,

metadata.title: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation

text: recursive algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and graph algorithms. Formal models of computation

metadata.title: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation

text: Formal models of computation including finite automata and Turing machines. Limitations of computation arising from fundamental notions of algorithm

metadata.title: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation

text: notions of algorithm and from complexity-theoretic constraints. Reductions, undecidability and NP-completeness. Same as ECE 374. Prerequisites: One

metadata.title: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation

text: ECE 374. Prerequisites: One of CS 173, MATH 213; CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to CS and blended CS

text: CS 400 Accelerated Fundamentals of Computing I. The first class in a sequence of two classes that introduces students to the basic concepts in
to the basic concepts in computing with an emphasis on the fundamental techniques for solving computational problems. Topics include: core
Topics include: core programming concepts (variables, data types, conditional expressions, loops, functions), basic data structures, searching and
structures, searching and sorting algorithms, and data exploration and visualization. No prior programming experience is required. No undergraduate
is required. No undergraduate credit. 3 graduate hours. Restrictions: Restricted to postbaccalaureate students with a non-computing background.
a non-computing background. Restricted to GCRT:ComputingFundam - UIUC or GCRT:ComputingFundam ONL- UIUC..
CS 401 Accelerated Fundamentals of Algorithms I. The first class in a sequence of two classes that introduces students to the theoretical foundations
the theoretical foundations of computer science. Topics include counting, sets, functions, decision trees, recursion, binary numbers, basic graph
binary numbers, basic graph theory, depth first search and breadth first search, algorithms for computing shortest paths, data structures like stacks
data structures like stacks and queues, big O notation and asymptotic analysis, complexity classes like P and NP, and reductions. No undergraduate
reductions. No undergraduate credit. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisites: CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to GCRT:ComputingFundam - UIUC or
- UIUC or GCRT:ComputingFundam ONL- UIUC. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to O/C Engineering City Scholars students.

CS 461 Computer Security I. Fundamental principles of computer and communications security and information assurance: ethics, privacy, notions of
ethics, privacy, notions of threat, vulnerabilities, and risk in systems, information warfare, malicious software, data secrecy and integrity issues,
secrecy and integrity issues, network security, trusted computing, mandatory and discretionary access controls, certification and accreditation of
and accreditation of systems against security standards. Security mechanisms: authentication, auditing, intrusion detection, access control,
detection, access control, cryptography, security protocols, key distribution. Same as ECE 422. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.
hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisites: CCS 225 and one of CS 361, STAT 361, ECE 313, MATH 362, MATH 461, MATH 463 or STAT 400. Restrictions:
or STAT 400. Restrictions: Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to

metadata.title: Topics in Societal and Ethical Impacts of Computer Technology

text: of computer technology on aspects of society and ethics such as: freedom versus the rule of law in cyberspace; social discourse; privacy; livelihoods

text: CS 465 User Interface Design. A project-focused course covering fundamental principles of user interface design, implementation, and evaluation. Small
and evaluation. Small teams work on a term-long project that involves: analysis of the problem domain, user skills, and tasks; iterative prototyping
tasks; iterative prototyping of interfaces to address user needs; conducting several forms of evaluation such as cognitive walkthroughs and usability
walkthroughs and usability tests; implementation of the final prototype. Non-technical majors may enroll as non-programmers who participate in all
who participate in all aspects of the projects with the possible exception of implementation. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisites:
hours. Prerequisites: CS 225. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign.

commercial or industrial problems. Work involves planning, design, and implementation. Extensive oral and written work is required both on-campus and

CS 499 Senior Thesis. Research and thesis development experience in computer science under guidance of a faculty member. Literature search, oral
Literature search, oral presentation, analysis and implementation, paper preparation, and completion of a written thesis. 3 undergraduate hours. No
3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisites: Consent of instructor. Restrictions: Restricted to
Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science major(s). Restricted to students with Senior class standing. Restricted to Undergrad - UrbanaChampaign..
CS 507 Topics in Cryptography. Modern cryptography helps realize a variety of tasks: from computations on and proofs about secret data, to verifiably
secret data, to verifiably offloading computation to untrusted clients, to making programs unintelligible while preserving functionality, to testing
functionality, to testing untrusted quantum devices. Covers a selection of such cutting-edge topics in cryptography. We will understand how any
We will understand how any adversary that counters the security of modern protocols can be transformed into an adversary that contradicts basic
that contradicts basic mathematical assumptions. We will understand key ideas in recent cryptography research and identify new directions and
identify new directions and problems for the future. May be repeated, up to 8 hours in a single term, to a total of 16 graduate hours, if topics
16 graduate hours, if topics vary. Credit is not given towards a degree from multiple offerings of this course if those offerings have significant
offerings have significant overlap, as determined by the CS department. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s).
or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 508 Manycore Parallel Algorithms. page 64 - Computer Science, Fall 2025 Same as ECE 508. See ECE 508. Restrictions: Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 511 Advanced Data Management. Advanced concepts in data management and information system design and implementation, and recent developments in the
recent developments in the field. 1) Relational roots, objects and extensibility, query languages, data indexing, query processing, transaction
query processing, transaction processing, benchmarks, and 2) semi-structured data and unstructured data, information extraction, information
extraction, information integration, web search and mining, and other emerging directions in the field. Prerequisites: CS 411. Restrictions:
CS 411. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 512 Data Mining Principles. An advanced course on principles and algorithms of data mining. Data cleaning and integration; descriptive and
integration; descriptive and predictive mining; mining frequent, sequential, and structured patterns; clustering, outlier analysis and fraud
outlier analysis and fraud detection; stream data, web, text, and biomedical data mining; security and privacy in data mining; research frontiers.
mining; research frontiers. Prerequisites: CS 412. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 521 Advanced Topics in Programming Systems. Advanced topics in building and verifying software systems, selected from areas of current research
areas of current research such as: model checking and automated verification, testing and automated test generation, program synthesis, runtime
program synthesis, runtime verification, machine learning and its applications in the design of verified systems, formal analysis of machine learning
analysis of machine learning algorithms, principles of programming languages and type systems. May be repeated if topics vary. Credit is not given
vary. Credit is not given towards a degree from multiple offerings of this course if those offerings have significant overlap, as determined by the
overlap, as determined by the CS department. Prerequisites: CS 374 or ECE 374; CS 421. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics
Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted

CS 527 Topics in Software Engineering. Fault-tolerant software, software architecture, software patterns, multi-media software, and knowledge-based
software, and knowledge-based approaches to software engineering. Case studies. Prerequisites: CS 428, CSE 429 or CS 429. Restrictions: Restricted to
Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..

text: CS 538 Advanced Computer Networks. Advanced concepts in computer networks, including congestion control, quality of service, naming, routing, wireless
naming, routing, wireless networks, Internet architecture, measurement, network security, and selected recent research directions. Prerequisites: CS
directions. Prerequisites: CS 438 or ECE 438. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 540 Deep Learning Theory. A rigorous mathematical course covering foundational analyses of the approximation, optimization, and generalization
and generalization properties of Deep Neural Networks. Topics include: constructive and non-constructive approximations with one hidden layer;
with one hidden layer; benefits of depth; optimization in the NTK regime; maximum margin optimization outside the NTK regime; Rademacher complexity,
Rademacher complexity, VC dimensino, and covering number bounds for ReLU networks. Evaluation is primarily based on homeworks, with a smaller project
with a smaller project component. The course goal is to prepare students perform their own research in the field. Restrictions: Restricted to
Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 542 Statistical Reinforcement Learning. Theory of reinforcement learning, with a focus on sample complexity analyses. Specific topics include MDP
Specific topics include MDP basics, finite-sample analyses of online (i.e., exploration) and offline (i.e., batch) RL with a tabular representation,
a tabular representation, finite-sample analyses of online and offline RL with function approximation, state abstraction theory, off-policy
theory, off-policy evaluation (importance sampling), and policy gradient. The course goal is to provide a comprehensive understanding of the
understanding of the statistical properties of RL under various settings (e.g., online vs offline), preparing the students for doing research in the
for doing research in the area. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 543 Computer Vision. Same as ECE 549. See ECE 549. Restrictions: Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to MENG:Elec & Comp Eng ONL -UIUC..
CS 545 Machine Learning for Signal Processing. Fundamentals of machine learning and signal processing as they pertain to the development of machines
the development of machines that can understand complex real-world signals, such as speech, images, movies, music, biological and mechanical
biological and mechanical readings, etc. Hands-on examples of how to decompose, analyze, classify, detect and consolidate signals, and examine
signals, and examine various commonplace operations such as finding faces from camera feeds, organizing personal music collections, designing speech
collections, designing speech dialog systems and understanding movie content. Prerequisites: MATH 415; one of CS 361, STAT 361, MATH 461, MATH 463 or
361, MATH 461, MATH 463 or STAT 400. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..

metadata.title: Advanced Topics in Natural Language Processing

text: dialogue systems, language grounding, and natural language generation. Review of classic as well as state-of-the-art techniques and remaining

metadata.title: Advanced Topics in Natural Language Processing

text: techniques and remaining challenges, and exploration of recent proposals for meeting these challenges. Intended for graduate students doing research

metadata.title: Advanced Topics in Natural Language Processing

text: CS 567 Social Signals and Social Media. Online social interactions occur in many arenas important to society and human well-being, but are mediated
well-being, but are mediated through algorithmic interventions that alter the users expectations in these social spaces. This class explores the
This class explores the presentation of self, the presentation of collectives, the presentation of news, and social dynamics in these online
dynamics in these online spaces--and how algorithmic intervention shapes them from the perspective of social signaling theory. Topics covered
theory. Topics covered include: the evolution of algorithmic matchmaking (as in online resume/ interviews and dating sites), why people share
sites), why people share misinformation, the mitigation of trolling, ethics, and bias in social media systems. Upon completion of this course,
completion of this course, students will have an up-to-date understanding of the design social media interfaces with incentive structures from social
structures from social signaling theory. Prerequisites: CS 465 or equivalent or permission of instructor. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer
Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 571 Combinatorial Mathematics. Same as MATH 580. See MATH 580. Restrictions: Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 574 Randomized Algorithms. Basic and advanced concepts in the design and analysis of randomized algorithms. Sampling; concentration inequalities
concentration inequalities such as Chernoff-Hoeffding bounds; probabilistic method; random walks, dimension reduction; entropy; martingales and
entropy; martingales and Azuma's inequality; derandomization. Randomized algorithms for sorting and searching; graphs; geometric problems. Basics of
geometric problems. Basics of pseudorandomness and randomized complexity classes. Prerequisites: One of CS 473, CSE 414, or MATH 473; one of MATH
414, or MATH 473; one of MATH 461, MATH 463 or STAT 400. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to
major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign. Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 579 Computational Complexity. Turing machines; determinism and non-determinism; time and space hierarchy theorems; speed-up and tape compression;
and tape compression; Blum axioms; structure of complexity classes NP, P, NL, L, and PSPACE; complete problems; randomness and complexity classes RP,
and complexity classes RP, RL, and BPP; alternation, polynomial-time hierarchy; circuit complexity, parallel complexity, NC, and RNC; relativized
NC, and RNC; relativized computational complexity; time-space trade-offs. Same as ECE 579. Prerequisites: One of CS 473, CSE 414, MATH 473, CS 475 or
CSE 414, MATH 473, CS 475 or MATH 475. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 580 Topics in Algorithmic Game Theory. A theoretical CS course covering advances in algorithmic game theory. This includes study of strategic,
includes study of strategic, computational, learning, dynamic, and fairness aspects of games and markets (organizations that involves rational and
that involves rational and strategic agents). In particular, topics will include computation and complexity of equilibria, mechanism design,
equilibria, mechanism design, fair-division, dynamics in games and markets, price-of-anarchy etc.. These topics arise from applications such as
from applications such as online marketplaces (like Lyft, Uber, eBay, sponsored search, TaskRabbit), social networks, recommendation systems, kidney
systems, kidney exchange, spectrum auction, etc., and thereby will prepare students for related research and/or industry jobs. Prerequisites: CS 473.
jobs. Prerequisites: CS 473. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 582 Machine Learning for Bioinformatics. This graduate course on bioinformatics introduces a selection of topics in computational biology and
in computational biology and bioinformatics, with special emphasis on current problems in regulatory genomics and systems biology. Computational
biology. Computational approaches discussed will focus on Machine Learning techniques such as Bayesian inference, graphical models, supervised
graphical models, supervised learning and network analysis. Bioinformatics topics will be introduced through lectures by instructor and research
by instructor and research paper presentations by students, and include regulatory sequence analysis, cistromics, epigenomics, regulatory network
regulatory network reconstruction, non-coding variant interpretation, and protein structure and function prediction. A research project involving
A research project involving real data analysis with techniques related to course content is mandatory and will help prepare students for
help prepare students for bioinformatics research. Restrictions: Restricted to Computer Science or Bioinformatics major(s). Restricted to Graduate -
Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign..
CS 584 Embedded System Verification. Same as ECE 584. See ECE 584. Prerequisites: CS 426. Restrictions: Restricted to Graduate - Urbana-Champaign.
